content: I've removed the example in Output section (an example is already in Example section), and the tag "Guessing digits".
Added "write answer" to stub generator so that the initial default code shows the syntax for debugging and outputting the answer.

Jamproject, could you please explain to me impossible x=6, y=8 test case?
Burt can guess that 2+4=6 in max 3 turns, and Sarah can guess 2*4 in max 2 turns. Why is this impossible?

The statements are soooooo unclear.
What is the starting set ? What are the rules to remove one number from the set ? ...

There are only 45 combinations, a hard-coded solution is doable if the hacker is motivated enough :)

Providing a+b and ab as inputs could increase the number of possibilities.
Maggie could give her buddies inconsistent numbers, which they could detect - or not!
That might even make the puzzle more amusing to solve.
Your test 1 and validator 1 are the same. You should change one of them to avoid hardcoded solution.

Thank you for your comment!

Yes there are only 45 combinations but if someone want to harcode it, he'll need to take a piece of paper and test every combinaison. it means also that he get the point  and the code itself is not very difficult.

I could extend the range between 1 and 20 but all of the numbers between 10 and 20 can be guess easily by sarah.

If I provide a+b and a*b, I just need to add two for  loop at the beginnig to find a and b but  it doesn't change the code. How does it increase the number of possibilities?

If I provide incoherent a+b and a*b, it will be noticable after those two for loop.

That being said, It's a good idea to add a bit of complexity to the exercise.

Hello Boulet!

Désolé je réponds un peu tard.
Je n'ai pas précisé les règles car pour moi cela fait partie du challenge (je les ai données dans la réponse au commentaire plus haut).
Que veux-tu dire par starting set?

Hello! 

Did you code something or did you try on a piece of paper?
What's your method?
Basically, you should remove turns after turns the couple of digits whose the sum (or multiplication) give a number which is unique in the set of sums (or multiplication) of the remaining couple of digit. You do that until: 
   - That unique number is a solution
   - You can't remove any couple anymore (in this case it's impossible)
I've increased the difficulty from Medium to Hard in view of the low community success ratio (solved by 184 out of 746, or 24.66%).

Thank you for your response, Jamproject.
It's difficult for me to write a program if I don't understand the facts, but I'll describe the steps for my algorithm.

Examining Validator 4: 

Find all a, b numbers for which sum is equal to 6 => Burt has set {(1,5), (2,4), (3,3)}; 
Find all a, b numbers for which product is equal to 8 => Sarah has set {(1,8), (2,4)};

If they are guessing numbers in ascending order:
- first Burt guesses wrongly that a and b are 1 and 5
- than Sarah tries 1 and 8
- than Burt guesses correctly 2 and 4 => "(2,4) BURT 2".

Other possibility, worst case scenario:
Burt guesses in 3 turns (length of his set), Sarah guesses in 2 turns (length of her set). Output is Sarah's minimum combinations => "(2,4) SARAH 2".

I believe that impossible solution would be only if x is not the x is not the sum of the a and b, or y is not the product of a and b, or if a and/or b are > 9 or < 1.

Ok, I get it.

Sarah and Burt do not guess a couple of digits at each turn. They just say "Yes I know what's the answer" or "No I don't". Maybe it is unclear in the statements but Maggie just gives the papers. Then she is useless in the game.

Exemple for the test case:
-Turn 1:
           -Burt has 3 possibilities: he says "I don't know"
           -Sarah understands that the sum can't be 2, 3,17,18 
             because there's only one way to get them.
           - So, the digits can't be (1,1) (1,2) (9,8) and (9,9)
           - She still have 2 possibilities and say "I don't know"
-Turn 2:
            - Burt understands that the product can't be 5, 7,....,72,81 
             because there's only one way to get them.
            - He can eliminate corresponding digits
            - He still don't know
Etc
Thank you, this explains the problem :)

It would make hard-coding more difficult I suppose, if you allow a range of 1-100 for a+b and ab.
Most of the invalid combinations would be easy to guess, but I suppose some interesting cases might arise if both the sum and the product correspond to valid combinations of two different (a,b) couples.
Assuming the two players can't tell each other the guessed numbers (i.e. they will write them down and pass them to Maggie without the other player knowing their value) then the other player has a chance to deduce that Maggie gave them wrong numbers, but I suppose there will be cases where he/she can't.
That would complexify the possible outpouts ("guess valid/invalid in x turns / couldn't guess) and thus hinder the hackers a bit more :)

Actually, there is only one couple (a+b,a*b) which allows more than one (a,b) couple (6,5)->(1,5)(2,3) (and the sum and product are inverted-not compatible with the game). 
But I will make the modification to give a+b and a*b instead of a and b :)
